abstract: This article proposes an approach of adult education focused on human activity analysis. Part 1 a) specifies the concept of activity as a translation of social practices for analytical purposes, b) describes our research perspective and c) summarizes its most significant empirical and conceptual contributions. Part 2 provides an extension in two directions. The first comes from the impossibility to adopt, in this approach, an epistemology which distinguishes facts and values; it argues in favor of collaborative inquiries methods oriented towards developmental transformation of activity and involving joint working groups of researchers and professionals. The second proposes an extension of this approach to social practices other than labor, which leads to three consequences: i) the designing of new research objects such as “the course of existence” and “the course of existence relating to a practice” which opens onto new theoretical and methodological problems; ii) an ethical and axiological involvement of researchers into the collaborative inquiry; iii) a critical position towards current approaches in adult education, and the proposal of a developmental approach summarized by the expression “education for becoming”.
